stem: The nurse assesses a client presenting with 'dark, tarry stools.' Highlight the assessment findings that are most concerning for the development of hypovolemic shock.
passage: A 52-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of melena. She has a history of long-term NSAID use for chronic back pain. The client's heart rate is 122 bpm. Her blood pressure while lying flat is 108/62 mmHg, but it drops to 84/50 mmHg when she sits up. The nurse notes the client's skin is cool, pale, and clammy to the touch. Capillary refill time is 4 seconds in the fingernails. The client reports a pain level of 2 out of 10. The client's abdomen is soft and non-tender to palpation. The client appears restless and anxious.

rationale.correct: Signs of compensated and uncompensated hypovolemic shock include tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension (a drop in SBP >20 or DBP >10), cool/pale/clammy skin (peripheral vasoconstriction), delayed capillary refill (>3s), and restlessness/anxiety (cerebral hypoxia).
rationale.incorrect: History of NSAIDs and pain level are context. A soft, non-tender abdomen is a 'normal' finding in this case and doesn't indicate the severity of the bleed or the progression to shock.

reviewUnits.heading: Stages of Shock
reviewUnits.body: Stage I (Compensated): Tachycardia, normal BP (low in orthostatics). Stage II (Decompensated): Hypotension, cool/clammy, oliguria. Stage III (Irreversible): Multi-organ failure.

clinicalPearls: Orthostatic vital signs are a sensitive indicator of volume loss of >15-20%.

questionTrap.trap: Waiting for the patient to be hypotensive while lying flat.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Tachycardia and 'cool/clammy' skin often precede formal hypotension in shock.

answerBreakdown.label: Critical Cues
answerBreakdown.content: The identified evidence represents objective clinical markers of physiological instability.

mnemonic.title: CHIPS
mnemonic.expansion: Cold skin, Heart rate high, Inadequate perfusion, Pressure low, Sensorium altered
